headline: Experiencing bus delays
subhead: The Daily Californian tracked NextBus real-time departure predictions to evaluate the the occurrence of bus delays
author: Seokhyeon Ryu

sections.text: Sahil Hansalia, a junior, takes the 51B every day to get to class. In the morning, he checks the Transit app on his phone to see when the next bus arrives. Today, the app predicts the bus will arrive at his stop in 10 minutes. He knows he has a few minutes before leaving his apartment. Most days, the prediction is accurate. The bus does arrive in 10 minutes. But some days, the the prediction can change. "I’d say 20 percent of the time, it get pushed back and it’s annoying," Sahil said. After checking the app five minutes later, he sees that the prediction has actually updated and increased to 12 minutes. He decides to walk instead. Delays like these are an inevitable experience for those who make plans around the bus. Particularly nearby campus and on Shattuck Ave, there are many long waits for the bus to arrive. The main culprit appears to be traffic, which can come to a standstill on busy hours. The Daily Californian investigated the frequency and period of bus delays at stops surrounding campus. AC Transit publishes a schedule for a subset of stops along a route. For example, the 51BBerkeley Amtrak has scheduled times for five stops along that route. The remaining stops, however, do not have this information. Instead, AC Transit recommends passengers rely on “real-time” predictions provided by NextBus, a company that partners with transit agencies to provide transit information. AC Transit collects GPS data from its buses and sends the information to NextBus, which predicts their departure times at each stop, taking into account historical traffic patterns, according to their website. The prediction service is available on AC Transit’s website and NextBus app. The Transit app shows real-time data on AC Transit buses directly from NextBus.

Since most stops don’t have a published schedule, in order to measure bus delays, The Daily Californian measured the time difference between when the NextBus service says a bus is 30 minutes from a stop and when it actually arrives (according to the service). 

Let us say you are at the Bancroft Way & Telegraph Ave bus stop.

Each arc represents one bus trip, starting 30 minutes before the bus is scheduled to arrive. In the example above, the arc ends when the bus actually arrived, 12 minutes late. Below, each chart shows a random selection of 100 trips on a given route.

Some routes, such as F San Francisco and 18 Lake Merritt BART, have relatively unpredictable arrivals. Others, such as 51B Berkeley Amtrak and 36 West Oakland BART, are more reliably on time.

Average delay also varies, as F Berkeley experiences close to no delays, on average, while the F San Francisco in the other direction averages several minutes late. More on methodology is explained at the end of this article.

Stops, not just routes, have variation in delay. In the bubble map below, each stop is represented by a circle whose size is proportional to the stop’s average delay (that includes all routes at that stop). Delays are highest along Shattuck southbound and Piedmont southbound. There is also a noticeably large average delay on Bancroft Way and Telegraph Ave.
